newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX to cut noon break for Euroyen, JGB futures.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX to cut noon break for Euroyen, JGB futures.

text.p: Singapore's futures exchange said on Tuesday it plans to eliminate the midday break for floor trading of Euroyen and Japanese government bond futures and options contracts from October 28.

The Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX) said in a circular to its members that the one-hour break at 0315 GMT would be discontinued, bringing it in line with the practice for Eurodollar futures and options contracts.
Some futures traders, already chafing under a move by SIMEX to extend the Euroyen pit session by one hour earlier this month, were less than enthusiastic about the change.
"They're taking everything away from us now. With Tokyo closed (for lunch), that is the time we'll be more quiet," said a trader with an Asian institution.

"Tokyo dealers will be out for lunch. I don't see the locals giving up their lunch break and it's way too early for Europe to be trading. I don't see any extra business coming out of it," said a dealer with a European institution.
He said SIMEX was probably seeing an additional 1,000 lots traded in the Euroyen pit since it moved to extend the closing time to 1205 GMT on October 15.
"But it's not clear whether they've stolen additional market share or whether people are just taking their own time because they know they have longer," he said.

Some traders saw the move as a competitive measure by SIMEX in the light of a decision by the Tokyo International Financial and Futures Exchange (TIFFE) to reduce its morning break by 30 minutes to one hour from November 5.
"The attitude is, they shave half-an-hour -- we'll stay open all the time," said the trader with the European house.
But a spokesman for SIMEX said the extended hours were not being introduced for competitive reasons.
"Our basis is that we're streamlining the floor trading hours. That's the only reason," he said.
